text: I looked at the Go language code on GitHub. I couldn't see anywhere it draws to the screen. So is the visual editor not part of that code base, and is something else you have written, which is not available? i was wondering if you were using Electron or some other framework for the drawing. Yes the JS code does have maltese in it. in one of the date functions. I was looking at one of the main .JS files. When you copy and paste code and include other libraries you do end up with surprising stuff. It doesn't matter, but i can assure you i am not making up words like Xahar and Għada

So is the visual editor not part of that code base, and is something else you have written, which is not available? i was wondering if you were using Electron or some other framework for the drawing. Yes the JS code does have maltese in it. in one of the date functions. I was looking at one of the main .JS files. When you copy and paste code and include other libraries you do end up with surprising stuff. It doesn't matter, but i can assure you i am not making up words like Xahar and Għada

text:
Personally I like this more than the previous one with the illustrated character. But I think there are still some weaknesses in the delivery compared to the product.

What interests me most about Storybook is that you can create code that uses many different services without having to write a custom integration or find a suitable API client library(which may or may not be an official one). I feel when writing such code, the integration-specific parts tend to dominate the complexity and a lot of effort is duplicated across projects. Being able to outsource all that to a provider dedicated to keeping the integrations working and high-quality seems like a great convenience that people would pay money for.

I feel like this aspect isn't really conveyed well to someone unfamiliar with the product right now.

Also compare to the landing pages of Zapier or IFTT, which much more concisely(and visually) explain the value that the product provides, rather than mockups or screenshots of what the product looks like(which I don't think are very helpful for a landing page, though in storybook's case having some code snippets might be nice):

<https://ifttt.com/>
<https://zapier.com/>

To me Zapier's:
> Easy automation for busy people. Zapier moves info between your web apps automatically, so you can focus on your most important work.
feels more evocative and concrete than:
> Storyscript is a language, editor, database, infra and community all-in-one. Create holistic apps, tools and workflows blazing fast that power your team
which while more descriptive is also more plain and only highlights one rather vague benefit("blazing fast". It also isn't clear here to me _what_ is blazing fast). Compare to Zapier highlighting two concrete ones("easy", "focus on your most important work").

In any case I think the product is exciting and I believe it has a lot of potential, so good luck!

is blazing fast). Compare to Zapier highlighting two concrete ones("easy", "focus on your most important work").

text: ah, wow, nice find, yes the timeago lib probably uses that form i18n and yes the “editor” is not yet open source as it just large hack we are not proud of and which we don’t want people to rely on too much as it subject to a lot of changes

text: <@UJKKBAMLL> A large contingent of people here are interested in the issues with code, and see the failings of our tools as a consequence of the failings of code itself. If you have things to say about the issues inherent to code, you should share them in a way that we can all read and respond to and reflect on, rather than spin these discussions off to DMs. If you don't want to derail this latest thread of feedback on your homepage that makes perfect sense — I invite you to spin up a new thread over in <#C5T9GPWFL|general> with your thoughts on code itself. That's what this community is for.
